ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Universal Pure is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program. This program addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the process equipment at the facility. 



Universal Puresenior management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities. Universal Pure's safety and environmental policies as they relate to the ammonia refrigeration system are administered by the Maintenance and Refrigeration Manager, who conducts inspections of the facility to ensure compliance.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



Universal Pure is located at 8 Lee Boulevard, in Malvern, Pennsylvania. The facility is located to the south of the Pennsylvania Interstate 76 and approximately 1 mile north of US Highway 202. The area immediately surrounding the facility is rural with a mixture of light commercial, industrial, and residential areas.  The facility was acquired by Universal Pasteurization (now Universal Pure) in 2015, and began operations in June 2015.  



The primary business of Universal Pure is to provide cooling and storage of food products. In order to conduct operations, the facility maintains a refrigeration system containing anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance.  The refrigeration system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, and then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for cold storage, dock operations, and HPP processing.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Universal Pure ammonia

refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the facility also operates in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation.  



The facility including the ammonia system was designed and constructed in accordance with the International Mechanical Code applicable at the time of construction, which specifically outlines requirements for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  These safety features include ammonia sensors in the engine room as well as sensors in the cold rooms and vent line.  In addition, the majority of the ammonia is maintained inside the engine room and just outside of the engine room (condensers). All pressure vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves that relieve into a common header that vents to the atmosphere.



In addition to the International Mechanical Code, Universal Pure has developed a preventive maintenance program that utilizes the services of a professional refrigeration contractor to complete regularly scheduled inspections and tests of the ammonia refrigeration system as well as repairs as needed to process equipment. 



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The EPA's RMP Program defines "accident" as the following: 



"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process. 



The release must have caused at least one of the following: 



?     On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a)); or 

?     Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42(a))." 



There have been no reportable releases in this facility's five year accident history since Universal Pure became the owner of the facility and began operations in 2015. 

 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Universal Pasteurization facility has an emergency ac

tion plan in effect.  The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of this PSM/RMP document. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:



  1.)  To save lives.

  2.)  To minimize and avoid injuries.

  3.)  To protect the environment.

  4.)  To minimize property damage.



The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations.

In case of an ammonia emergency, the facility plans to evacuate all employees and contractors and put the facility's action plan into play to address the situation.  If necessary, this facility will alert the local emergency responders (fire department) for assistance. The facility coordinates emergency response efforts with the fire department on a periodic and ongoing basis.



CONTINUOUS IMPROVEMENT



Universal Pure is committed to providing a safe work environment for our employees.  This facility regularly looks at the process to determine if changes can be made to improve safety with the Process Safety Management and Risk Management Programs.
